TEXT: The applicants are a mother ( the first applicant ) and her son ( the second applicant ) . They are both NORP nationals , born in DATE and DATE respectively . They are represented before ORG of ORG ( Perheen Suojelun Keskusliitto ) .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

PERSON is the child of PERSON marriage to a citizen of GPE . The marriage ended in DATE . She had sole custody of PERSON In DATE the applicants moved from GPE to GPE . PERSON apparently started to gain more weight than was average for a child of his age . In DATE the applicant mother took him to ORG in GPE for examinations . It appears that a psychologist there reported PERSON ’s overweight condition to the social authorities , which appointed a support person for the family .

On DATE PERSON brought PERSON in for further examinations at ORG . PERSON was voluntarily placed in the department for child psychiatry ( although it is alleged that this was contrary to PERSON wishes ) . PERSON reacted strongly to his placement . PERSON allegedly found out at a later stage that the staff was severely punishing children at the hospital . In DATE she repeatedly requested that PERSON be discharged , but the staff underlined the importance of his continued hospital care . After the hospital treatment had lasted for DATE , the applicant mother demanded that PERSON be returned home in DATE .

On DATE and DATE PERSON was informed of a proposal to place PERSON in public care . According to a written notice , this proposal was to be considered by the local ORG ( sosiaali- ja terveyslautakunta , social- och hälsovårdsnämnden ; hereinafter “ the ORG ” ) on DATE .

On DATE the Board placed PERSON in public care , finding that the applicant mother lacked the resources to set the necessary boundaries for PERSON and that the applicants had “ too close a relationship ” . ORG estimated that PERSON ’s public care was likely to last a long time . PERSON was to be placed in the special children ’s home . PERSON appealed to ORG ( lääninoikeus , länsrätten ) , complaining that the written notice had referred to DATE and not DATE ) . She did not appeal against the public care decision as such .

In DATE PERSON allegedly discovered that PERSON had been severely punished by hospital staff as bruises were found on his body . It was PERSON ’s firm wish to go home . The applicant mother ’s wish that PERSON be discharged immediately was refused .

On DATE PERSON was placed in the special unit of the children ’s home . On DATE the police decided , in the absence of sufficient evidence , to discontinue the investigation initiated as a result of a report made by the applicant mother about the suspected assault on PERSON at ORG .

On DATE the director of ORG approved the proposal to modify the substitute care as from DATE ( PERSON was transferred from ORG to the children ’s home ) . The applicant mother appealed against this decision , firstly to the ORG and then to ORG . She did not appeal to ORG against the ORG ’s later decision of DATE upholding the director ’s decision .

On DATE ORG , without holding an oral hearing , rejected the applicant mother ’s appeal against the decision of DATE to place PERSON in public care . The court found that PERSON and her representative had both been informed orally before the ORG ’s meeting that the written notice had been incorrect and that ORG would consider the matter on DATE . The court upheld the ORG ’s decision , stating , inter alia , the following :

“ The shortcomings in the care of PERSON , especially taking into account his illness , are seriously threatening his health and further development . The mother is not able to take care of his upbringing at the present time . The open care measures have proved to be insufficient . The public care is found to be in the interest of the child . ORG has , thus , been obliged to take PERSON into public care and to organise his substitute care . ”
The applicant appealed to ORG ( korkein hallinto - oikeus , högsta förvaltningsdomstolen ) .

PERSON sister and brother - in - law then informed the social workers in charge of the case that they could care for PERSON in their home so as to avoid his placement in a children ’s home . They were well - off and had a big house with a separate flat which could be used by the applicants . The request was apparently rejected . In proceedings instituted before ORG ( käräjäoikeus , tingsrätt ) , PERSON sister , PERSON , and brother - in - law , ORG , requested shared custody of PERSON together with PERSON

On DATE the ORG decided to uphold the decision concerning the change of substitute care made by the director on DATE . As noted earlier , the applicant mother did not appeal to ORG against the decision of DATE .

According to a social worker ’s notes from a meeting which she and apparently other social workers had with PERSON on DATE , PERSON had requested to be allowed to visit PERSON every day at the children ’s home . It had nevertheless been agreed at the meeting that PERSON would visit his mother at home DATE and that the applicant mother would visit him at the children ’s home for TIME on CARDINAL different weekdays and telephone him DATE at TIME .

The first applicant later alleged that no such agreement had been reached . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE she pointed out that the care order had not restricted her access to PERSON and that she intended to visit him every day .
On DATE the ORG restricted PERSON access to PERSON until DATE . She was allowed to receive PERSON in her home DATE , visit him for TIME on CARDINAL different weekdays and telephone him DATE at TIME .

On DATE the ORG prolonged the restriction until DATE , after having heard the applicant and her legal counsel at its meeting . According to the ORG ’s decision , PERSON had a serious overweight condition and eating disorder . It appeared that his mother could not set any boundaries for him as PERSON had managed to gain QUANTITY during a TIME visit to his mother ’s home . The applicant appealed against the prolonged restriction , requesting an oral hearing . On DATE ORG rejected the appeal without holding an oral hearing . There is no right of appeal from a ORG decision concerning the restriction of access rights .
On DATE ORG did not consider the merits of the applicant mother ’s appeal concerning the changes made to the substitute care as no appeal is allowed against such decisions .

On DATE the director of the ORG prohibited on a short - term emergency basis the right of access of the applicant mother to PERSON , including telephone contact , until DATE as the mother - son relationship was found to be too symbiotic and dependant . Moreover , PERSON had started to become very aggressive and stressed in anticipation of the visits and phone calls . He had thrown tantrums and acted in a threatening way towards other children and adults . According to the decision , PERSON had been hospitalised on DATE because of his disorderly behaviour . It was considered that PERSON had to be “ removed from his mother ’s sphere of influence ” and be given “ the peace required by his treatment ” . PERSON had to integrate into the children ’s home .

A further access prohibition was issued on DATE and lasted until DATE as PERSON had again acted so aggressively at the children ’s home that a psychiatrist had to be called to visit him . The decision was taken by the director of ORG . This was a short - term emergency decision which also prohibited the access of GPE and ORG to the child .
On DATE ORG granted the request for the shared custody of PERSON after having heard , inter alia , ORG . ORG had expressed a negative opinion on the request .

On DATE PERSON requested ORG to revoke PERSON ’s public care . She submitted , inter alia , that PERSON had not received proper care in the children ’s home and that she would move to the house of her sister and brother - in - law in order to provide him with optimal care .

During negotiations with the social workers in charge of the case PERSON requested that she be allowed to take PERSON with her to ORG of ORG in order to obtain support and therapy . This was allegedly refused . Allegedly , the social authorities also prevented PERSON from taking PERSON to be examined by a private therapist specialising in the upbringing of children .

On DATE ORG rejected PERSON appeal against the confirmation of the care order . It had obtained written submissions from ORG and a written opinion from ORG . This opinion relied on a written opinion submitted by PERSON , a child and youth psychiatrist of ORG in the Social Welfare and ORG ( sosiaali- ja terveysalan tutkimus- ja kehittämiskeskus ) . PERSON submitted a rejoinder , pointing out , inter alia , that PERSON opinion had been exclusively based on the documents at her disposal and on her own speculations .

In DATE PERSON was moved from the children ’s home to the home of his joint custodians , GPE and ORG , and PERSON , but his public care was maintained . PERSON withdrew her request that PERSON ’s public care be revoked .
On DATE the head social welfare officer of ORG approved the changes to the substitute care as from DATE according to the care plan .
On DATE the director of ORG decided to terminate PERSON ’s public care .

The relevant legislation is outlined in the ORG ’s judgment of CARDINAL DATE in the case of PERSON and GPE ( no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL , to be published in the ORG ’s official reports ) . Those provisions of particular relevance to the present case are described below .

When the need for child welfare is caused primarily by inadequate income , deficient living conditions or lack of housing , or when these factors constitute a serious obstacle to the rehabilitation of a child and family , local authorities must provide adequate financial support without delay , and improve the family ’s housing conditions . Open - care assistance includes both general support measures in accordance with LAW ( sosiaalihuoltolaki , socialvårdslagen , Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) and specific assistance , inter alia by appointing a lay helper or a support family , by providing adequate therapy and by assisting the child in his or her personal needs through financial and other support . The assistance must be provided in co - operation with the child and its parents or other carers ( section CARDINAL of LAW ) .

According to section CARDINAL of LAW , ORG must take a child into care and provide substitute care for him or her if ( a ) the child ’s health or development is seriously endangered by lack of care or other conditions at home , or if the child seriously endangers his or her health and development by abuse of intoxicants , by committing an illegal act other than a minor offence , or by any other comparable behaviour , ( b ) the measures of assistance in open care are not appropriate or have proved to be inadequate ; and ( c ) foster care is considered to be in the best interests of the child . PERSON care shall be provided without delay where it is needed and is in the best interests of the child ( section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL ) . The public care ceases when the child turns CARDINAL ( the age of majority ) or marries ( section CARDINAL ) . Care orders may be appealed to the administrative courts .

The child ’s custodians , biological parents and de facto carers must be heard in respect of a proposal to issue or revoke a public care order or to place a child outside his or her original home . They must further be notified of the decision taken ( section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL , of LAW , as amended by Act no . GPE ) . The hearing procedure is governed by LAW ( hallintomenettelylaki , lagen om förvaltningsförfarande , Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . Under LAW of LAW , a party must be afforded an opportunity to reply to any claims put forward by others as well as to any evidence that may affect a decision to be taken .

A child who has attained DATE is entitled to state his or her opinion in child welfare matters . A child who has attained DATE is entitled to be heard as stipulated in CARDINAL of LAW ; he or she is also entitled to demand the social services and other support measures ( section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL , of LAW ) .

According to section CARDINAL of LAW , a child who is being cared for outside his or her original home shall be ensured those important , continuous and secure human relations which are important for his or her development . The child is entitled to meet his or her parents and other close persons and to keep in touch with them ( subsection CARDINAL ) . ORG must support and facilitate the child ’s contacts with his or her parents and other close persons ( subsection CARDINAL ) .

According to section CARDINAL of LAW and section CARDINAL of LAW ( lastensuojeluasetus , barnskyddsförordningen , Degree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , ORG or the director of a ORG home may restrict the right of access of a child in foster care to its parents or other persons close to him or her if ( a ) such access clearly endangers the development or safety of the child ; or if ( b ) such a restriction is necessary for the safety or security of the parents , or the children or staff in the residential home . The restriction must be limited in time . It must mention the persons whose rights are being restricted , the kind of contacts concerned by the restriction and the extent of the restriction .

Any decision concerning public care , the transfer of a child into foster or other care outside his or her home , access restrictions and isolation of the child must be drawn up on a form approved by ORG ( section CARDINAL of LAW ) .

The care plan to be drawn up in respect of a child in public care must mention ( a ) the purpose and objectives of the placement ; ( b ) what kind of special support will be organised for the child , for the persons in charge of the child ’s care and upbringing and for the child ’s parents ; ( c ) how the child ’s right of access to its parents and other persons close to the child will be organised ; and ( d ) how after - care is going to be organised . According to section CARDINAL of LAW , the care plan must be elaborated in co - operation with those involved .

A ORG decision in respect of a public care order , the transfer of a child into foster care or the termination of public care may be appealed further to ORG . Other decisions of a county administrative court relating to child welfare measures can not be so appealed ( section CARDINAL of LAW ) .

If , in the course of his or her activities , an employee or elected official in health care , social welfare , education , the police or a parish finds out that a child is in evident need of family - oriented or individual child welfare , he or she must notify ORG without delay . Any other person may also contact ORG to this end ( section CARDINAL of LAW ) .
